description: a(1)=1; for n > 1, a(n) = sum of exponential divisors (or e-divisors) of n.
comments: The e-divisors (or exponential divisors) of x=Product p(i)^r(i) are all numbers of the form Product p(i)^s(i) where s(i) divides r(i) for all i.a(n) = n if and only if n is squarefree. - _Jon Perry_, Nov 13 2012
references: Fabrykowski, J. and Subbarao, M. V., The maximal order and the average order of multiplicative function sigma^(e)(n), in Theorie des nombres (Quebec, PQ, 1987), 201-206, de Gruyter, Berlin, 1989.
links: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Nicussor Minculete, Concerning some arithmetic functions which use exponential divisors, Acta Universitatis Apulensis, No. 28/2011, pp. 125-133.
Y.-F. S. Pétermann and J. Wu, On the sum of exponential divisors of an integer, Acta Math. Hungar. 77 (1997), 159-175.
formula: Multiplicative with a(p^e) = Sum_{d|e} p^d. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Apr 23 2002
example: a(8)=10 because 2 and 2^3 are e-divisors of 8 and 2+2^3=10.
mathematica: a[n_] := Times @@ (Sum[ First[#]^d, {d, Divisors[Last[#]]}] & ) /@ FactorInteger[n]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 71}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 06 2012 *)
prog: (PARI) a(n)=my(f=factor(n));prod(i=1,#f[,1],sumdiv(f[i,2],d,f[i,1]^d)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Nov 22 2011(Haskell)a051377 n = product $ zipWith sum_e (a027748_row n) (a124010_row n) where   sum_e p e = sum [p ^ d | d <- a027750_row e]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 13 2012
author: _Yasutoshi Kohmoto_
